Title: FACTBOX-McCain running-mate Palin outlines foreign policy
URL: FACTBOX-McCain running-mate Palin outlines foreign policy.txt
Text: Sept 12 (Reuters) - Republican vice presidential candidate  Sarah Palin, a little-known Alaska governor before becoming  John McCain's running mate in the Nov. 4 U.S. presidential  election, has begun to outline her foreign policy views.      Following are some of the positions she took in a series of  interviews with ABC News this week.           * On Iran and Israel:      'I believe that under the leadership of (Iranian President  Mahmoud) Ahmadinejad, nuclear weapons in the hands of his  government are extremely dangerous to everyone on this globe,  yes.'      'We have got to make sure that these weapons of mass  destruction, that nuclear weapons are not given to those hands  of Ahmadinejad, not that he would use them, but that he would  allow terrorists to be able to use them. So we have got to put  the pressure on Iran and we have got to count on our allies to  help us, diplomatic pressure.'      Asked whether it would be acceptable for Israel, if it felt  threatened, to take military action against Iran's nuclear  facilities, Palin said: 'We cannot second-guess the steps that  Israel has to take to defend itself.'           * On the 'Bush doctrine':      Asked if she agreed with the 'Bush doctrine,' Palin paused  and then asked, 'In what respect?'      Asked what she interpreted the Bush doctrine to be, she  replied, 'His world view.'      When the interviewer explained he was referring to the  doctrine Bush enunciated in September 2002 before the Iraq war,  Palin said:      'I believe that what President Bush has attempted to do is  rid this world of Islamic extremism, terrorists who are hell  bent on destroying our nation.'      When the interviewer defined the doctrine as U.S. President  George W. Bush's belief the United States has a right to make  pre-emptive strikes against countries that may attack it, Palin  said: 'If there is legitimate and enough intelligence that  tells us that a strike is imminent against American people, we  have every right to defend our country. In fact, the president  has the obligation, the duty to defend.'           * On the pursuit of al Qaeda/Taliban into Pakistan:      Asked if the United States had the right to make  cross-border attacks into Pakistan from Afghanistan without the  approval of the Pakistani government, Palin said:      'As for our right to invade, we're going to work with these  countries, building new relationships, working with existing  allies, but forging new, also, in order to, Charlie, get to a  point in this world where war is not going to be a first  option. In fact, war has got to be, a military strike, a last  option.'           * Pressed on whether the United States had the right to  make such cross-border attacks without approval, Palin said:      'In order to stop Islamic extremists, those terrorists who  would seek to destroy America and our allies, we must do  whatever it takes and we must not blink.'      'I believe that America has to exercise all options in  order to stop the terrorists who are hell-bent on destroying  America and our allies. We have got to have all options out  there on the table.'           * On the Russia-Georgia war:      Asked if the United States should try to restore Georgian  sovereignty over South Ossetia and Abkhazia, Palin said:      'We're going to continue good relations with (Georgian  President Mikheil) Saakashvili there. I was able to speak with  him the other day and giving him my commitment, as John  McCain's running ma

sentences.text: 'I believe that under the leadership of (Iranian President Mahmoud) Ahmadinejad, nuclear weapons in the hands of his government are extremely dangerous to everyone on this globe, yes.'
sentences.bias_description: The sentence uses emotionally charged language to emphasize the danger of nuclear weapons under Ahmadinejad's leadership, potentially evoking fear without a balanced perspective.

sentences.text: 'We have got to make sure that these weapons of mass destruction, that nuclear weapons are not given to those hands of Ahmadinejad, not that he would use them, but that he would allow terrorists to be able to use them. So we have got to put the pressure on Iran and we have got to count on our allies to help us, diplomatic pressure.'
sentences.bias_description: This sentence employs a sense of urgency and fear regarding the possibility of terrorists obtaining nuclear weapons through Ahmadinejad's government, emphasizing the need for pressure and alliances in a dramatic manner.

sentences.text: 'We cannot second-guess the steps that Israel has to take to defend itself.'
sentences.bias_description: The use of the phrase 'cannot second-guess' implies a strong endorsement of Israel's actions without question, suggesting a bias towards unconditionally supporting Israel's military decisions.

sentences.text: 'I believe that what President Bush has attempted to do is rid this world of Islamic extremism, terrorists who are hell bent on destroying our nation.'
sentences.bias_description: This statement employs emotionally charged language to describe the intentions of terrorists, using phrases like 'hell bent on destroying our nation' to evoke a strong emotional response.

sentences.text: 'If there is legitimate and enough intelligence that tells us that a strike is imminent against American people, we have every right to defend our country. In fact, the president has the obligation, the duty to defend.'
sentences.bias_description: The assertion of 'every right' and 'obligation, the duty to defend' presents a subjective opinion as an unquestionable fact, blurring the line between personal perspective and objective reporting.

sentences.text: 'As for our right to invade, we're going to work with these countries, building new relationships, working with existing allies, but forging new, also, in order to, Charlie, get to a point in this world where war is not going to be a first option. In fact, war has got to be, a military strike, a last option.'
sentences.bias_description: This sentence expresses a subjective opinion on the approach to international relations and conflict, advocating for a specific strategy (building relationships, avoiding war) without presenting it as one of many possible perspectives.

sentences.text: 'In order to stop Islamic extremists, those terrorists who would seek to destroy America and our allies, we must do whatever it takes and we must not blink.'
sentences.bias_description: The use of the phrase 'do whatever it takes' and 'must not blink' conveys a sense of urgency and absolutism in combating terrorism, potentially oversimplifying complex strategies and ethical considerations.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias regarding foreign policy discussions, particularly in its portrayal of the dangers posed by certain leaders and the urgency of actions to combat terrorism. The biases tend to manifest through the use of emotionally charged language, opinionated assertions, and a strong endorsement of specific political and military strategies without a balanced presentation of alternative viewpoints.

Title: Nigerians doubt election fairness -- reform chief
URL: Nigerians doubt election fairness -- reform chief.txt
Text: By Felix Onuah      ABUJA, Aug 12 (Reuters) - Most Nigerians question whether  the country can hold free and fair elections in an atmosphere of  political violence, vote-rigging and lax federal oversight, the  head of the election reform panel said on Tuesday.      Muhammadu Uwais, a former chief justice, said the government  must do more to ensure electoral bodies are independent enough  to conduct federal and state elections.      'Nigerians now express deep frustration over the lack of  credibility of the electoral process and their inability to  elect leaders of their choice,' he said after a meeting with  President Umaru Yar'Adua.      Yar'Adua, whose own electoral victory more than a year ago  is being challenged in court over alleged fraud, set up an  election reform panel in August 2007 shortly after he took  office.      The 21-member committee was charged with providing a report  to Yar'Adua by the end of August, but the president extended the  deadline on Tuesday to the end of the year.      The panel requested more time to digest all the suggestions  from public hearings on how to improve the electoral process.      Nigeria, a country of 140 million people and Africa's  biggest oil producer, returned to civilian rule in 1999 after  three decades of almost continuous military dictatorship.      Uwais said the committee would recommend that elections be  raised to international standards, the electoral body be made  autonomous, and the performance of political parties improved.      In setting up the committee last year, Yar'Adua noted that  almost every election since 1959 vote that ushered in  independence had been followed by controversy, which threatened  political stability and development.      Nigeria is one of the world's most corrupt countries,  according to independent watchdog Transparency International,  and public office is mostly seen as an avenue to personal  wealth.      Pro-democracy campaigners say politicians stop at almost  nothing to win office and get their slice of the cake.      (For full Reuters Africa coverage and to have your say on  the top issues, visit: http://africa.reuters.com/)   (Writing by Randy Fabi; Editing by Tume Ahemba and Andrew  Dobbie)   ((randolph.fabi@thomsonreuters.com; Abuja Newsroom + 234 9 461  3214, Reuters Messaging: randolph.fabi.thomsonreuters.com))    Keywords: NIGERIA ELECTIONS/

sentences.text: Most Nigerians question whether the country can hold free and fair elections in an atmosphere of political violence, vote-rigging and lax federal oversight, the head of the election reform panel said on Tuesday.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence presents a subjective opinion about the state of elections in Nigeria, implying judgment about the country's electoral process without providing concrete evidence.

sentences.text: 'Nigerians now express deep frustration over the lack of credibility of the electoral process and their inability to elect leaders of their choice,' he said after a meeting with President Umaru Yar'Adua.
sentences.bias_description: The use of anecdotal evidence, in this case, the expression of frustration by Nigerians, to generalize about the credibility of the entire electoral process introduces bias by not considering a broader, more representative evidence.

sentences.text: Yar'Adua, whose own electoral victory more than a year ago is being challenged in court over alleged fraud, set up an election reform panel in August 2007 shortly after he took office.
sentences.bias_description: The phrase 'alleged fraud' implies a negative connotation and judgment about the electoral victory, suggesting wrongdoing without presenting a balanced or neutral perspective.

sentences.text: Nigeria, a country of 140 million people and Africa's biggest oil producer, returned to civilian rule in 1999 after three decades of almost continuous military dictatorship.
sentences.bias_description: The contrast between 'civilian rule' and 'almost continuous military dictatorship' uses word choice to emphasize a positive change in a way that could be seen as oversimplifying a complex historical and political transition.

sentences.text: Nigeria is one of the world's most corrupt countries, according to independent watchdog Transparency International, and public office is mostly seen as an avenue to personal wealth.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence generalizes the level of corruption in Nigeria and the motives of individuals in public office without providing a nuanced or statistically representative analysis, potentially reinforcing negative stereotypes.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias regarding the state of elections and governance in Nigeria, with a general bias tendency towards presenting subjective opinions, anecdotal evidence, and generalizations without a balanced or neutral perspective.

Title: RPT-UPDATE 1 - Russia could strike Poland over U.S. shield-Ifax
URL: RPT-UPDATE 1 - Russia could strike Poland over U.S. shield-Ifax.txt
Text: (Repeats to additional subscribers, text unchanged)      MOSCOW, Aug 16 (Reuters) - A top Russian general on Friday  said Poland's deal with the United States to set up parts of a  missile defence shield on Polish territory lays it open to a  possible military strike, a Russian news agency reported.      Col-General Anatoliy Nogovitsyn, deputy chief of the general  staff, told Interfax that Russian military doctrine would allow  for a possible nuclear strike.      Poland agreed on Thursday to host elements of a U.S. global  anti-missile system after Washington agreed to boost Poland's  own military air defences.      'The USA is engaged in an anti-missile defence for its own  government, and not for Poland. And Poland, in deploying  (elements of the system) opens itself to a military strike. That  is 100 percent,' Interfax quoted Nogovitsyn as saying.      Nogovitsyn said Russia allows nuclear weapons to be used in  circumstances defined by its current security doctrine.      The Russian government revamped its national security  doctrine in 2000, broadening the range of conflicts in which  nuclear weapons could be used.      'It is written clearly: We will use it in instances against  governments that have nuclear weapons; against allies of  countries with nuclear weapons, if they somehow enable them,' he  said.      Washington says the missile system is aimed at protecting  the United States and its allies from long-range missiles that  could in the future be fired by Iran or groups such as al Qaeda.      The Kremlin has long said that was untrue, and has opposed  the shield as a threat to Russia. The 10 interceptor missiles to  be based at a site in northern Poland compare with Russia's own  nuclear arsenal of more than 5,000 ballistic warheads.      In agreeing to deploy elements of the U.S. missile shield,  Poland 'becomes an actionable object. Those targets are  destroyed in the first order,' Nogovitsyn said.      Tension between Moscow and Washington has risen in the past  week, since Georgia's attempt to re-take its separatist region  of South Ossetia by force provoked a massive counter-attack by  Russia.   (Reporting by Chris Baldwin, editing by Tim Pearce)  ((christopher.baldwin@reuters.com, Moscow Newsroom +7 495 775  1242))    Keywords: GEORGIA OSSETIA/POLAND

sentences.text: A top Russian general on Friday  said Poland's deal with the United States to set up parts of a  missile defence shield on Polish territory lays it open to a  possible military strike, a Russian news agency reported.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence engages in speculation by suggesting that Poland's agreement with the United States for a missile defense shield could lead to a military strike, without concrete evidence to support such a claim.

sentences.text: 'The USA is engaged in an anti-missile defence for its own  government, and not for Poland. And Poland, in deploying  (elements of the system) opens itself to a military strike. That  is 100 percent,' Interfax quoted Nogovitsyn as saying.
sentences.bias_description: The use of 'That is 100 percent' in the context of a speculative claim about Poland's vulnerability to a military strike due to the missile defense deployment implies a strong, unsubstantiated opinion as fact.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias regarding the topic of Poland's agreement with the United States for a missile defense shield, with a general bias tendency towards speculative and opinionated assertions about the potential military implications for Poland.

Title: Bear Stearns deal helped calm markets - Lockhart
URL: Bear Stearns deal helped calm markets - Lockhart.txt
Text: CHATTANOOGA, Tennessee, March 27 (Reuters) - The Federal  Reserve-backed move to rescue Bear Stearns <BSC.N> has helped  restore market confidence, but the question of fairness can  only be answered by shareholders, a top Fed policy-maker said  on Thursday.      'I think overall the approach has been effective,  considering the focus is on financial system stability. As to  the fairness of the deal, I think that's essentially for the  board of Bear Stearns and JP Morgan to determine,' said Atlanta  Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart.      JP Morgan Chase <JPM.N> bought the ailing investment bank  for $2 a share on March 16 after the Fed agreed to take control  of a $30 billion portfolio of Bear Stearns assets. JP Morgan   has since lifted the purchase price to $10 a share and will  take the first $1 billion of loss on the portfolio.   (Reporting by Burton Frierson and Alister Bull; Editing by Dan  Grebler)   ((+1-202-354-5820, e-mail: alister.bull@reuters.com))  Keywords: USA FED/LOCKHART BEAR

overall_bias.conclusion: The article does not seem to exhibit bias. It provides a factual report on the Federal Reserve-backed rescue of Bear Stearns and includes statements from a top Fed policy-maker without introducing any elements of bias.

Title: Turkey widens EU talks, expects French fairness
URL: Turkey widens EU talks, expects French fairness.txt
Text: By David Brunnstrom      LUXEMBOURG, June 17 (Reuters) - Turkey said on Tuesday it  expected France, long an opponent of Turkish EU membership, to  treat its entry negotiations fairly and openly during its  six-month presidency beginning next month.      At a Luxembourg accession conference, Turkey and the EU  opened two new 'chapters', covering company law and intellectual  property rights, bringing the total under discussion to eight of  35. Ankara, if successful in the slow-moving negotiations, is  not expected to join until 2015 at earliest.      Turkey's progress over the last three years has been  hindered by French resistance, disputes with EU member Cyprus,  EU concerns over human rights in Turkey and the perception in  Europe that Turkey is slow to put reforms into practice.      Turkey's chief EU negotiator, Foreign Minister Ali Babacan,  told a news conference after the talks in Luxembourg that Turkey  expected the EU to honour its commitments and open chapters with  Turkey once it met technical requirements.     'We expect that the French presidency will be a fair,  impartial and transparent presidency as we have been told on  various occasions. We believe our EU accession process will be  further advanced during the French presidency.'      Babacan reiterated complaints that Turkey's progress was  being held up by 'political' considerations of some EU states.            PARTNERSHIP?      'We would like to think that negotiations can advance in  line with the technical readiness of Turkey,' he said.      European Commission Director-General Michael Leigh said the  EU executive was ready to open seven more chapters with Turkey  -- in areas ranging from food safety to social policy -- as soon  as the country met the benchmarks required.      'I expect that during coming months, further progress can be  made,' he told the news conference.      To the annoyance of Ankara and many EU capitals, France  wants to restrict talks to those chapters which could be used as  the basis of a future 'privileged partnership', short of  membership. Turkey rejects any notion of such a 'partnership'.      The European Commission has called on Turkey to implement  stalled reforms on state aid, decentralisation, ombudsman law  and upgrading the powers of the Court of Auditors.      A bid by prosecutors to shut down the ruling AK Party for  alleged Islamist activities is seen casting further political  uncertainty over the accession process.       Opponents to Turkish membership argue that the vast country  would be a drain on EU finances, that as a Muslim nation it  could not integrate well with mainstream European culture, or  that its human rights policies are far short of requirements.      Ankara argues it has a fast growing economy with a young  population and that its cultural and religious roots, tempered  by a strong Western orientation, would allow it to act as a  bridge to the Muslim world.   (Editing by Ralph Boulton)   ((david.brunnstrom@reuters.com ; +32 2 287 6839; Reuters  Messaging: david.brunnstrom.reuters.com@reuters.net ))    Keywords: TURKEY EU/

sentences.text: Turkey said on Tuesday it expected France, long an opponent of Turkish EU membership, to treat its entry negotiations fairly and openly during its six-month presidency beginning next month.
sentences.bias_description: The use of 'long an opponent' implies a negative connotation towards France's stance on Turkish EU membership, suggesting a historical and entrenched bias against Turkey's entry, which could influence the reader's perception.

sentences.text: Turkey's progress over the last three years has been hindered by French resistance, disputes with EU member Cyprus, EU concerns over human rights in Turkey and the perception in Europe that Turkey is slow to put reforms into practice.
sentences.bias_description: The phrase 'hindered by French resistance' and 'perception in Europe' introduces a negative framing, suggesting that external factors, particularly from France and the EU, are unjustly impeding Turkey's progress, which could bias the reader against these entities.

sentences.text: Turkey's chief EU negotiator, Foreign Minister Ali Babacan, told a news conference after the talks in Luxembourg that Turkey expected the EU to honour its commitments and open chapters with Turkey once it met technical requirements. 'We expect that the French presidency will be a fair, impartial and transparent presidency as we have been told on various occasions. We believe our EU accession process will be further advanced during the French presidency.'
sentences.bias_description: The expectation of 'fair, impartial and transparent presidency' implies a preconceived judgment that past presidencies may not have been so, suggesting a biased view of the EU's treatment of Turkey's accession process.

sentences.text: Babacan reiterated complaints that Turkey's progress was being held up by 'political' considerations of some EU states.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence implies that certain EU states are intentionally using political considerations to hinder Turkey's progress, suggesting a one-sided view that portrays Turkey as a victim of unjust political interference within the EU.

sentences.text: 'We would like to think that negotiations can advance in line with the technical readiness of Turkey,' he said.
sentences.bias_description: This statement implies a belief that Turkey's technical readiness is not being adequately recognized in the negotiation process, suggesting a subjective opinion on the matter rather than an objective assessment.

sentences.text: To the annoyance of Ankara and many EU capitals, France wants to restrict talks to those chapters which could be used as the basis of a future 'privileged partnership', short of membership. Turkey rejects any notion of such a 'partnership'.
sentences.bias_description: The use of 'annoyance' and the framing of Turkey's rejection of a 'partnership' as absolute without further context introduces a bias by portraying France's proposal and Turkey's stance in a negative light.

sentences.text: Opponents to Turkish membership argue that the vast country would be a drain on EU finances, that as a Muslim nation it could not integrate well with mainstream European culture, or that its human rights policies are far short of requirements.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence highlights negative stereotypes and generalized statements about Turkey as a Muslim nation, suggesting an inherent bias against its membership based on cultural and religious factors, which could influence the reader's perception negatively.

sentences.text: Ankara argues it has a fast growing economy with a young population and that its cultural and religious roots, tempered by a strong Western orientation, would allow it to act as a bridge to the Muslim world.
sentences.bias_description: The use of 'tempered by a strong Western orientation' is a positive framing that implies a favorable balance between Turkey's cultural and religious roots and Western values, suggesting a biased portrayal of Turkey's cultural integration and its role in the Muslim world.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias regarding the topic of Turkish EU membership, with a general tendency to portray Turkey in a positive light while casting France and certain EU states in a negative or obstructive role. The biases identified include Word Choice Bias, Opinionated Bias, Political Bias, and Discriminatory Bias, influencing the reader's perception of the fairness and justifiability of the EU accession process for Turkey.

Title: Regional leaders doubt fairness of Zimbabwe poll
URL: Regional leaders doubt fairness of Zimbabwe poll.txt
Text: MBABANE, June 25 (Reuters) - Southern African leaders said  on Wednesday that holding Zimbabwe's presidential election on  Friday could undermine the legitimacy of the result.     'It is the considered opinion of the organ summit that  holding the election under the current circumstances may  undermine the credibility and legitimacy of its outcome,' said a  security troika of the Southern African Development Community in  a statement.    Keywords: ZIMBABWE ELECTION/GROUP

sentences.text: 'It is the considered opinion of the organ summit that  holding the election under the current circumstances may  undermine the credibility and legitimacy of its outcome,' said a  security troika of the Southern African Development Community in  a statement.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence presents the opinion of the security troika as a fact, without providing evidence or allowing for alternative perspectives, thus blurring the line between objective reporting and personal perspective.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article contains an instance of Opinionated Bias regarding the Zimbabwe election, where the opinion of the security troika is presented as a definitive judgment without a balanced presentation of evidence or perspectives.

Title: Angola abuses threaten vote fairness -rights group
URL: Angola abuses threaten vote fairness -rights group.txt
Text: By Michael Georgy      JOHANNESBURG, Aug 13 (Reuters) - Intimidation of Angola's  opposition and meddling in the country's electoral commission  threaten chances of a fair vote in the September parliamentary  election, Human Rights Watch said on Wednesday.      It is the first national vote for 16 years in Angola, which  is booming because of soaring oil revenues and recovery from  civil war. Angola wants the vote to set an example on the  continent after flawed polls in Kenya and Zimbabwe.      But Human Rights Watch said in a report that conditions  ahead of the Sept. 5 election did not point to a fair ballot.      'The conditions for free and fair elections start long  before election day,' said Georgette Gagnon, Africa director at  New York-based Human Rights Watch, in a report.      'Less than a month before elections, it's clear Angolans  aren't able to campaign free from intimidation or pressure. And  unless things change now, Angolans won't be able to cast their  votes freely.'      The official campaign kicked off on Aug. 5 with 10 parties  and four coalitions competing for votes. Each party will be  given five minutes of television time each day and 10 minutes on  the radio to lure voters.      A total of 5,198 candidates will fight for 220 parliamentary  seats in a country that rivals Nigeria as Africa's biggest oil  producer, but where two-thirds of the population live on less  than $2 a day.      Based on missions to Luanda and four provinces, Human Rights  Watch said Angola's government is 'failing to fully ensure the  right to free elections, and other rights critical to a fair  poll, including the freedoms of expression and of assembly'.            SECURITY CONCERNS      'Major areas of concern include the government's obligations  to safeguard freedom of assembly and expression and access to  the media by all stakeholders, and to establish an impartial  national electoral body,' it said.      'The government has also failed to provide adequate security  to political parties participating in elections and to ensure  political tolerance and full participation of citizens.'      Angola's government denies accusations of rights abuses.      In a rare radio address this month, dos Santos appealed to  all political parties to maintain the peace as the country  recovers from the 27-year civil war that ended in 2002. he  called for an election that is an example to the world.      On Monday, Angolan police detained 13 people campaigning for  the main UNITA opposition party in the Rangel area outside the  capital Luanda, Catholic Radio Ecclesia reported.      Police told the radio they were accused of holding a rally  without notifying authorities and for disrupting traffic.      Many political observers say UNITA, a former guerrilla  movement, is unlikely to unseat dos Santos's ruling MPLA, which  holds 129 seats out of 220. UNITA has 70 seats.      The parliamentary poll will be followed by a presidential  election in 2009. Dos Santos, who has ruled since 1979, is  expected to run.      The European Union has sent 90 election observers to Angola  and other missions are expected.   (Editing by Matthew Tostevin)   ((michael.georgy@reuters.com; +27 11 775 3168; Reuters  Messaging:michael.georgy.reuters.com@reuters.net))   (For full Reuters Africa coverage and to have your say on the  top issues, visit: http://africa.reuters.com/)    Keywords: ANGOLA ELECTION/

sentences.text: Intimidation of Angola's opposition and meddling in the country's electoral commission threaten chances of a fair vote in the September parliamentary election, Human Rights Watch said on Wednesday.
sentences.bias_description: The use of the word 'intimidation' and 'meddling' carries a negative connotation and implies judgment about the actions, suggesting a lack of fairness without presenting a balanced view.

sentences.text: But Human Rights Watch said in a report that conditions ahead of the Sept. 5 election did not point to a fair ballot.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence presents the opinion of Human Rights Watch as a fact, implying that the conditions are definitively unfair without providing a neutral perspective.

sentences.text: 'Less than a month before elections, it's clear Angolans aren't able to campaign free from intimidation or pressure. And unless things change now, Angolans won't be able to cast their votes freely.'
sentences.bias_description: The use of emotionally charged language such as 'clear', 'free from intimidation or pressure', and 'won't be able to cast their votes freely' aims to evoke a strong emotional response, potentially at the expense of a balanced or evidence-based perspective.

sentences.text: Based on missions to Luanda and four provinces, Human Rights Watch said Angola's government is 'failing to fully ensure the right to free elections, and other rights critical to a fair poll, including the freedoms of expression and of assembly'.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence presents the assertion by Human Rights Watch as a definitive judgment without providing specific evidence or references to support the claim that the government is 'failing to fully ensure' these rights.

sentences.text: 'Major areas of concern include the government's obligations to safeguard freedom of assembly and expression and access to the media by all stakeholders, and to establish an impartial national electoral body,' it said.
sentences.bias_description: The use of the phrase 'major areas of concern' and the assertion of the government's 'obligations' without concrete evidence may speculate on the government's intentions or capabilities without a basis in fact.

sentences.text: Angola's government denies accusations of rights abuses.
sentences.bias_description: The use of 'denies accusations' implies a defensive stance and may subtly suggest guilt, especially when juxtaposed with preceding statements that carry negative connotations.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias regarding the upcoming parliamentary election in Angola, particularly in its portrayal of the government's actions and the fairness of the electoral process. The biases identified include Word Choice Bias, Opinionated Bias, Emotional Sensationalism Bias, Unsubstantiated Claims Bias, and Speculation Bias, indicating a general tendency to present a negative and potentially unbalanced view.

Title: Yoko Ono loses bid to bar use of "Imagine" in film
URL: Yoko Ono loses bid to bar use of "Imagine" in film.txt
Text: NEW YORK, June 2 (Reuters) - John Lennon's sons and widow,  Yoko Ono, on Monday lost a battle to block the use of the song  'Imagine' in the documentary 'Expelled: No Intelligence  allowed.'      Ono, her son Sean Ono Lennon, and Julian Lennon, John  Lennon's son from his first marriage, along with privately held  publisher EMI Blackwood Music Inc filed suit in April in  Manhattan federal court seeking to bar the filmmakers and their  distributors from continuing to use 'Imagine' in the movie.      They said the film, which looks at alleged discrimination  against scientists and teachers who support so-called  intelligent design as an alternative to Darwin's theory of  evolution, used the song without their permission.      But on Monday U.S. District Judge Sidney Stein found in  favor of the filmmakers based on a 'fair use' doctrine. 'That  doctrine provides that the fair use of a copyrighted work for  purposes of criticism and commentary is not an infringement of  copyright,' the judge said.      The documentary features Ben Stein, an actor, comedian and  former speechwriter for President Richard Nixon.      The suit, which sought unspecified damages, named the  film's producers and distributors -- Premise Media Corporation,  C&S Production LP and Rocky Mountain Pictures.      Lennon recorded 'Imagine' in 1971 and in 2004, Rolling  Stone magazine ranked it No. 3 on their list of the 500  Greatest Songs of All Time, according to the lawsuit.   (Reporting by Christine Kearney; Editing by Michelle Nichols  and Cynthia Osterman)   ((nyc.buro@reuters.com, ph: +1 646 223 6280))  Keywords: LENNON/FILM

overall_bias.conclusion: The article does not seem to be biased. It provides a factual account of the legal battle over the use of the song 'Imagine' in the documentary 'Expelled: No Intelligence allowed,' without displaying any evident bias towards any of the involved parties or the subject matter.
